comments:
BE 209 the first laboratory course in the Bioengineering curriculum. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. 

Many students described this class as “entertaining” despite its 6-hour length. Students generally agreed that the experiments were “interesting” and “a lot of fun.” 

Professor Burdick was described by most students as a “phenomenal teacher” who “goes out of his way” to help students. 

Several students reported wishing that they had received more time to complete the experiment and write the lab. Many students also wished that they had been given examples of previous lab reports so that they would know what to include. Some students suggested including a lecture to go over the material to accompany the lab. 

This review is based on the 4 student comments that were submitted.

BE 209 is split up into two parts; the first part is going over statistics information and the second part is doing experiments in the lab. There is a final project, which spans about a month’s time.

Several students felt that the statistics portion of the course went very rapidly, which caused confusion. Many found that it was difficult to do the homework based off the PowerPoint slides. Some students also lamented that assignments required an older version of Excel found only on certain computers around campus. Several students wished there had been a textbook or more assigned reading for reference. 

Students overwhelmingly approved of the course’s lab portion, however, claiming to have learned a lot from it. While many students “dreaded the pressure of the six-hour lab, it was more stimulating due to the subject matter and being able to understand what bioengineering entails.” Many found the labs to be very stressful due to the great amount of preparation and write-up required. Students also complained that the group work in labs was unfairly assessed. 

Many students found Dr. Widenbrant to be helpful in explaining the labs and helping out with the procedures. Many, however, also found her to be a harsh grader. One student felt that “she [provided] a lot of feedback but not many suggestions for improvement.” As a result, students found it “difficult to know what she expected and/or liked seeing in lab reports as far as content goes.”

The class received average ratings from students overall, and while it is required for BE majors, it is not recommended for non-majors. Students taking BE 209 are required to be enrolled in BE 200 and to have completed the physics and chemistry laboratories scheduled during their first year. BE 209 is the first laboratory course in the Bioengineering curriculum. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. It is intended for the fall semester of the sophomore year.

This review is based on the 7 student comments that were submitted.

Several students felt that the statistics portion of the course went very rapidly, which caused confusion. Many found that it was difficult to do the homework based off the PowerPoint slides. Many students found Dr. Widenbrant to be helpful in explaining the labs and helping out with the procedures. Many, however, also found her to be a harsh grader. Students taking BE 209 are required to be enrolled in BE 200 and to have completed the physics and chemistry laboratories scheduled during their first year. BE 209 is the first laboratory course in the Bioengineering curriculum. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. It is intended for the fall semester of the sophomore year.

This review is based on the 7 student comments that were submitted.

BE 209 is the first laboratory course in the Bioengineering curriculum. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. 

Many students felt that this was a “fantastic” course and one of the “most interesting” classes in the curriculum, but many requested that they be given more background information before lab. Many students were reliant upon prior knowledge to complete the labs and felt that the TAs were not helpful. Several students described the statistics portion of the course as “frustrating” and many felt that the PowerPoint lectures were “unhelpful.” Students stated that office hours for this class were not held, resulting in an environment where it was “difficult to learn.” 

Despite this, students generally felt that this class taught them about scientific writing, lab techniques, and “how to work with a team.” 

This review is based on the 4 student comments that were submitted.
